Second Concert
Set For Feb. 19
At Shriver Hall

The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra will present its second
concert in its annual series of
Programs at JHU on Sunday,
February 19, at 4 p.m.
The Symphony will be conducted by Peter Herman Adler
and will feature Heinrich Joachim as guest soloist on the cello.
Tickets for the concert are
On sale in the Office of Alumni
Relations in Shriver Hall and
cost $1.00.
The program for the concert
Will include "Symphonie Fantastique" by Berlioz, "Coriolanus
Overture" by Beethoven, and the
Concerto in B minor for violo
and cello by Dvorak.

for this assembly has not been

in 1957.

Engineers!

The Johns Hopkins School of
Advanced International Studies
will soon begin construction of
a new $1,500,000 building, it
was announced today by Dr.
Francis 0. Wilcox, Dean of the
School.
Architectural plans and specifications are well under way.
Actual construction will begin
as soon as the School can take
possession of its new site at
1738-44 Massachusetts Ave., N.W.
The School's present property
at 1906 Florida Avenue, N.W.
and 1830 Nineteenth Street will
be sold and the proceeds applied
to the new building, Dean Wilcox said.
Construction of the new physical plant is part of a $4,247,000
program of improvement and
expansion which has received
support from six foundations:
Carnegie
Ford,
Rockefeller,
Corporation, W. K. Kellogg,
Avalon and Old Dominion. These

funds, expendable over a tenyear period, will permit strengthening of the research and instructional programs, expansion
of faculty, an increase in enrollment, and relocation to the
new site.
One of the principal advantages of the new location, Dean
Wilcox explained, is that it will
permit a closer relationship between the School and the
Brookings Institution, with advantages to both. Locating the
School adjacent to Brookings
was warmly endorsed by foundation officials and became an informal condition of some of the
grants.
The new S.A.I.S. building is
expected to provide gross floor
area of 65,400 square feet, housing the School's various educational activities now being carried on in three buildings at
the Florida Avenue location. It
will also house the Washington

Center of Foreign Policy .Research, which is affiliated with
the Sahool.

Last year we had the pleasure of meeting many
engineering and science seniors during our visit
to the campus. As a result of our discussions, a
gratifying number chose to join our company.
We'll be back on the dates below, and this
notice is your invitation to come in and see us.
if you're interested in joining a company that's
leader in fields-with-a-future, you'll be interested in the advantages Boeing can offer you.
Boeing is a major contractor on the advanced
Solid-fuel ICBM, Minuteman; on the boostglide vehicle, Dyna-Soar, and on the BomARc
defense missile system. Boeing's Vertol Division
is one of the country's foremost builders of
helicopters.
Boeing is also the nation's foremost designer
and builder of multi-jet aircraft. Production includes eight-jet B-520 missile bombers, KC-I35
jet transport-tankers and the famous Boeing 707,
720 and 727jet airliners.

In view of the fact that the
Student Council's first meeting
of the second semester failed to
take place due to its inability to
attract a quorum, the NewsLetter has asked some of the
more diligent members of this
year's SC for their diagnosis of
the malady which has befallen
Hopkins' student government.

kins, let us admit it. and abolish
this nonsense about developing
"The Whole Man."
Our real problem still lies in
the misunderstandings among
the Student Council, the Student Body, and the Faculty and
Administration. Assistance from
this latter group would greatly
help to solve our misunderstandings. If nothing else, I would
propose an • elected StudentFaculty Council. Properly designed and carried out, it would
raise The Hopkins to a new
height in prestige and educational accomplishment.

bly programs outlined elsewhere
in this paper, and the results
of the student faculty camp. The
challenge lies in improving the
program by improving the student Council, both in its personnel and in its operating procedures.

try to displace the evident inability and lack of interest of the
Council to the student body at
large is foolish; however, the fact
remains that in electing their
representatives, the students
have, without a doubt, been influenced by the likeable "Joe
College," the BMOC, complete
with the tab collar and continental cut. What has become
of efficiency, though? As a matter of fact, where has leadership
disappeared to?
But talking does no good.
Recall the numerous News-Letter
articles concerning attendance.
They haven't made the slightest
impression. What is needed, not
so much because it is a better
system (it would get more work
done however), is out and out
control by the administration.
Although we may argue that it
is undemocratic and a usurpation of the rights of the members of the community, there can
be little hesitation in saying that
Hopkins men need a few years
to cultivate responsibility toward
their campus. And in the interim, we can be sure that maturity of intention and purpose
would be provided by the administration.
If you object to this "radical"
view, show me that you can do
an adequate job—if so, you're
needed on the Student Council.

At long last we are going to have assembly programs.
With fine speakers presenting highly interesting talks,
each assembly is certainly worthy of support from the
whole Hopkins community—students included. With rousing turnouts, any Doubting Thomases will be convinced
that there is a need for a well-planned and executed assem- Lonnie Wall
bly program.
One semester of membership
This will be an exemplary test to determine whether in the Johns Hopkins Student

Too Much Rope
If there are any dorm students who read this editorial
column, and we suspect there are a few, we hope that a
word to the wise will be sufficient. Quite reputable statements have been carefully, and quietly, placed before the
Hopkins community to the effect that several more advisors
will take up residence in the dorms as a step towards
returning a bit more order (and sanity) to the dorms.
It is things like the few riots, damaged furniture and
property, and finally the false fire alarm that have brought
the administration to the end of their proverbial rope.
As any good citizen will explain to you, freedom of
action can not exist without knowledge of responsibility.
It is all too apparent that many of the dorm students,
and their 'leaders,' have no sense of responsibility.
Even though we are students, ourselves, and even
though we are very emphatically in favor of maintaining
a definite, un-proctored, responsible dorm freedom, it is
with very little compunction that we say that with dorm
advisors, proctors, tighter rules, and penalties the dorm
student is getting everything he deserves. In fact, students should not be campused or restricted—they should
be removed from the University. A little teeth in the
penalties would go a long way.
Perhaps in a few years the pendulum will swing the
other way, and dorm students will again have the freedom
they so loudly (and we so often) yell about.
But this comes with responsibility.

Dave Adams
I've been asked to comment
on the effect of the poor attendance by Student Council members at meetings this year and
on the mediocre record thus far
compiled by this year's body.
About four scheduled meetings have lacked quorums, so
no business could be conducted
at them. At almost every meeting some one, two or three members have been absent. Obviously this poor record of attendance
has decreased the productivity
of the Council. Those who are
absent from a scheduled meet-

ing rob the other Council members of the opportunity to hear
their views on any topic under
discussion. If those who are
absent number just four, the
result is that no meeting can
be held, no business can be
conducted, and those who have
come have wasted their time and
are discouraged.
Discouragement in this case,
I think, breeds lack of initiative
and interest. Very, very little
encouragement is given to any
elected representative at Johns
Hopkins. No students attend
Council meetings, very few attend class meetings, very few
offer constructive ideas, encouragement or support to their
representatives. That being the
situation, it is ,easy for the most
to
enthusastic representative
rapidly loose his original enthusiasm and become discouraged.
Even the most promising new
class officers usually fall into a
state of inactivity, except for
carrying out certain obligatory,
inescapable functions. And so
the classes accomplish little or
nothing. The Student Council,
however, being a body of 17 men,
is usually able to provide itself
from within with the encouragement and cooperation that it
does not receive from without.
This year, due in large part to
the attendance record, I think,
the mutual encouragement and
cooperation that have to exist
among members of the Council
have been much less in evidence
than in the past. One can blame
those who have been absent most
for any deficiencies or shortcomings of the Council, or one
can blame the President of the
Council or all the members of
the Council. But ultimately, I
think, a large portion of the
blame must go to the student
body.

McCoy Poloi
To the editors:
In the Johns Hopkins catalogue for undergraduates a university is described as a place
of academic freedom where a
student has the opportunity of
working, searching and discovering knowledge. Unfortunately
I found that this was not the
case when I attempted to register for a course given only in
McCoy College. I was told that
according to the advisory committee of McCoy there are only
two excuses acceptable for a day
student to take such a course:
Either an unavoidable conflict
must be present of day school
courses or the course must lie
in the fields of education and
accounting.
Since this statement is so contradictory to academic freedom,
I would suggest that the university change its wording of the
subject in the undergraduate
catalogue. Most important, I believe would be an attempt by the
university officials to include
popular McCoy courses in the
day school.
Alan Nogen

THE ENGINEERS HAVE HAIRY EARS
Today in this age of technology when engineering graduates
are wooed and courted by all of America's great industries, how
do you account for the fact that Rimbaud Sigafoos, who finished at the very top of his class at M.I.T., turned down hundreds of attractive job offers to accept employment as a machinery wiper at the Acme Ice Company at a salary of $20 a week
with a twelve-hour day, a seven-day week, and only fifteen
minutes for lunch?
I know what you are thinking: "Cherchez la femme!" You are
thinking that Mr. Acme, head of the Acme Ice Company, has
a beautiful daughter with whom Rimbaud is madly in love and
he took the job only to be near her.
Friends, you are wrong. It is true that Mr. Acme does have
a daughter, a large, torpid lass named Clavdia who spends all
her waking hours scooping marzipan out of a bucket and staring
at a television set which has not worked in some years. Rimbaud
has not the slightest interest in Clavdia; nor, indeed, does any
other man, excepting possibly John Ringling North.
So how come Rimbaud keeps working for the Acme Ice
Company? Can it be that they provide him with free Marlboro
Cigarettes, and all day long he is able to settle back, make
himself comfortable and enjoy the filter cigarette with the unfiltered taste?

(Continued from Page 4)
Is it necessary for you to
display your sense of humor in
such a crude manner, to derive
pleasure from such obnoxious
print? Mores, is it necessary
for you to abuse the freedom of
the press with such worthless
words? Well, I guess it is—if
you haven't outgrown that thirteen-year-old stage of life.
Freud could attach some lovely phrases to describe your complex, retarded behavior, but I
find that "immature" does the
job quite well.
Marjorie Berson
Editor-in-Chief
Goucher Weekly

Sorry Socialist
To the editors:
Having only recently received
copies of the News-Letter reporting our efforts to make the
Young Socialist available at
Hopkins University, I have finally been able to discover the
source of the conflicting testimony between Charles Vayne,
manager of the book store, and
myself. A phone call to Dean
Shaffer was enough to clarify
the unfortunate confusion. It
seems that Dean Shaffer, having told me that we had his

permission to place the Young
Socialist in the book store "on
the same basis as any other
periodical", directed me to negotiate with a Mr. Taylor, who I
understand, carries the title
"Plant Manager." It was Mr.
Taylor who instructed me that
he would not permit sale of the
Young Socialist at the book store
as it represented "only one point
of view, while Time, Life and
US News, presents all points of
view." Not being familiar with
Hopkins names, titles, or responsibilities, I assumed that I had
spoken to the Bookstore Manager. Allow me to publicly
apologize for having put such
foolish words into the Bookstore
Manager's mouth for which he
has just cause for righteous
indignation. Had Mr. Taylor
chosen to speak up, he could
have clarified the misunderstanding of titles.
It appears, however, that Mr.
Vayne, the Bookstore Manager,
has his own reasons for not
selling the Young Socialist "for
the reason that his (my italics)
book store does not handle
newspapers." Now, we must enter into a discourse on the definition of a newspaper,as opposed to a magazine, — both be-

ing periodicals. My, how the
lackeys of capitalism can twist
and squirm to dig up fine technicalities in order to prevent
Americans from reading "unkosher" thoughts, ideas, and information. Certainly, I can argue
that the Young Socialist is a
monthly magazine and Mr.
Vayne can retort that it is
printed on inexpensive newspaper print but why strain false
points raised by evasive bureaucrats.
The naked truth stands out for
all who have the honesty to see,
and that is that these men (and
those whom they represent), for
some reason which we would
all do well to investigate, do
not want to afford Hopkins students the opportunity to read
the Young Socialist. In order
to repair this deplorable abridgement of the right to read all
viewpoints in an academic institution, Hopkins students will
have to buy individual subscriptions to the Young Socialist until they organize themselves in
their fine tradition of fighting
for academic freedom to collectively resist this petty form of
tyranny over the minds of men.
(Continued on Page 6)

No,friends, no. Rimbaud is not allowed to smoke on the Job
and when he finishes his long, miserable day he has to buy his
own Marlboros, even as you and I, in order to settle back and
enjoy that choice tobacco, that smooth, mellow flavor, that incomparable filter, that pack or box.
Well, friends, you might as well give up because you'll never
in a million years guess why Rimbaud works for the Acme Ice
Company. The reason is simply this; Rimbaud is a seal!
He started as a performing seal in vaudeville. One night on
the way to the Ed Sullivan show, he took the wrong subway.
All night the poor mammal rode the B.M.T., seeking a helping
hand. Finally a kindly brakeman named Ernest Thompson
Sigafoos rescued the hapless Rimbaud.
He took Rimbaud home and raised him as his own, and
Rimbaud, to show his appreciation, studied hard and got excellent marks and finished a distinguished academic career as
valedictorian of M.I.T.
Rimbaud never complained to his kindly foster father, but
through all those years of grammar school and high school and
college, he darn near died of the heat! A seal, you must remember, is by nature a denizen of the Arctic, so you can imagine how poor Rimbaud must have suffered in subtropical
New York and Boston, especially in those tight Ivy League
suits.
But today at the Acme Ice Company, Rimbaud has finally
found a temperature to his liking. He is very happy and sends
greetings to his many friends.

As the communications needs of our nation
become steadily greater and more complex,
the Bell Telephone System is continuing its
pioneer work in microwave by "taking to the
get the word across.
air" more and more
To this end, Western Electric—the manufacturing arm of the Bell System—has the
monumental task of producing a large part of
the microwave transmission equipment that
knits our country together by shrinking thousands of miles into mere seconds.
In spite of its great technological strides,
the science of radio relay is a rapidly-changing
one. And new break-throughs and advances
are common occurrences. A case in point: our
Bell System "TH" Microwave Radio Relay.
This newest development in long-distance
telephone transmission will eventually triple
the present message-carrying capacity of existing long-haul radio relay installations. A fullscale system of 6 working and 2 protection
channels can handle 11,000 telephone messages at the same time.
To make microwave work takes a host of
special equipment and components: relay
towers, antennae, waveguides, traveling wavetubes, transistors, etc. But just as important,

it takes top-caliber people to help us broaden
our horizons into such exciting new areas as
communication by satellites!
And microwave is only part of Western
Electric's opportunity story. We have—right
now—hundreds of challenging and rewarding
positions in virtually all areas of telephony,
as well as in development and building of
defense communications and missile guidance
systems for the Government.
So,if your future is "up in the air," you owe
it to your career to see "what's up" for you at
Western Electric.

and more experienced Bill Kirby
from Towson.

After travelling to Ursinus
tomorrow, the Freshman basketball team plays its last home
game on Monday, February 13
against Drexel J.V.
Ed Greenberg led the freshman basketball team to victories
over PMC and Western Maryland, by scores of 56-48 and
69-58, respectively, by capturing
control of the boards and scoring
well.
In the P.M.C. game, Greenberg
was the Baby Blue Jays' prime
mover as he captured high of
22 rebounds, as well as 10 points.
Greenberg's helper in this
game was big Joel Sandberg.
Sandberg, after an average first
half, connected for 13 points in
the second half to complement
Greenberg's defensive work and
insure the victory. Phil Berger
with 11 and Mike Ratner with
10 were the other big scorers for
the Jays, with Ratner's work
under the boards being an excellent complement to Greenberg's
job there.
In the Western Maryland
game on February 6 at Homewood, Greenberg garnered 15 rebounds and scored 14 points in
the first half as the Jays jumped
to a decisive 24-13 lead at the
end of 10 minutes.
Schwartz Stars
In the second half, the frosh
proved that they were not a oneman team. Homer Schwartz,
who finished with 10, turned in
his finest offensive and defensive
effort of the season, and Mike
Ratner and Joel Sandberg also
turned in excellent accounts of
themselves. Sandberg scored 10
points, when he connected for
five of six shots. Ratner, who
finished with 11, turned in an
excellent offensive and defensive
performance, capturing 14 rebounds and playing a very fine
all-around game.
Perhaps the most inspired performance of the half, however,
was turned in by Mark Weiss.
Weiss, coming off the bench
with 7 minutes left in the game,
quickly proceeded to garner 6
rebounds and 11 points. He also
had the distinction of not missing a shot all evening, connectting for 3 for 3 from the floor
and 5 straight from the line.
While all this was going on,
Greenberg was in the process of
finishing the game with 20

points and 21 rebounds, although
he had to sit out a part because
of personal fouls.
In the last two minutes of the
game, Jack White, Pete Thompson and John Heller came in to
relieve the victorious Jays. Haller scored 2 and White closed
out the game by making both
halves of a 1 and 1 situation.
Not to be overlooked in this
array of figures is the fine work
of Phil Berger. Berger, who only
scored three points all evening,
nonetheless turned in a fine defensive effort, and played his
usual fine role as leader of the
Jays' floor game.
The game was otherwise notable for two things. The first of
these is the fine foul shooting
percentage of the team, which
hit for 21 of 24 penalty shots.
The other was that despite he
fine performance, the fledglings
showed the effects of the twoweek examination layoff.

The Johns Hopkins School of
Advanced International Studies
will soon begin construction of
a new $1,500,000 building, it
was announced today by Dr.
Francis 0. Wilcox, Dean of the
School.
Architectural plans and specifications are well under way.
Actual construction will begin
as soon as the School can take
possession of its new site at
1738-44 Massachusetts Ave., N.W.
The School's present property
at 1906 Florida Avenue, N.W.
and 1830 Nineteenth Street will
be sold and the proceeds applied
to the new building, Dean Wilcox said.
Construction of the new physical plant is part of a $4,247,000
program of improvement and
expansion which has received
support from six foundations:
Carnegie
Ford,
Rockefeller,
Corporation, W. K. Kellogg,
Avalon and Old Dominion. These

funds, expendable over a tenyear period, will permit strengthening of the research and instructional programs, expansion
of faculty, an increase in enrollment, and relocation to the
new site.
One of the principal advantages of the new location, Dean
Wilcox explained, is that it will
permit a closer relationship between the School and the
Brookings Institution, with advantages to both. Locating the
School adjacent to Brookings
was warmly endorsed by foundation officials and became an informal condition of some of the
grants.
The new S.A.I.S. building is
expected to provide gross floor
area of 65,400 square feet, housing the School's various educational activities now being carried on in three buildings at
the Florida Avenue location. It
will also house the Washington

Center of Foreign Policy .Research, which is affiliated with
the Sahool.

Too Much Rope
If there are any dorm students who read this editorial
column, and we suspect there are a few, we hope that a
word to the wise will be sufficient. Quite reputable statements have been carefully, and quietly, placed before the
Hopkins community to the effect that several more advisors
will take up residence in the dorms as a step towards
returning a bit more order (and sanity) to the dorms.
It is things like the few riots, damaged furniture and
property, and finally the false fire alarm that have brought
the administration to the end of their proverbial rope.
As any good citizen will explain to you, freedom of
action can not exist without knowledge of responsibility.
It is all too apparent that many of the dorm students,
and their 'leaders,' have no sense of responsibility.
Even though we are students, ourselves, and even
though we are very emphatically in favor of maintaining
a definite, un-proctored, responsible dorm freedom, it is
with very little compunction that we say that with dorm
advisors, proctors, tighter rules, and penalties the dorm
student is getting everything he deserves. In fact, students should not be campused or restricted—they should
be removed from the University. A little teeth in the
penalties would go a long way.
Perhaps in a few years the pendulum will swing the
other way, and dorm students will again have the freedom
they so loudly (and we so often) yell about.
But this comes with responsibility.

I've been asked to comment
on the effect of the poor attendance by Student Council members at meetings this year and
on the mediocre record thus far
compiled by this year's body.
About four scheduled meetings have lacked quorums, so
no business could be conducted
at them. At almost every meeting some one, two or three members have been absent. Obviously this poor record of attendance
has decreased the productivity
of the Council. Those who are
absent from a scheduled meet-

ing rob the other Council members of the opportunity to hear
their views on any topic under
discussion. If those who are
absent number just four, the
result is that no meeting can
be held, no business can be
conducted, and those who have
come have wasted their time and
are discouraged.
Discouragement in this case,
I think, breeds lack of initiative
and interest. Very, very little
encouragement is given to any
elected representative at Johns
Hopkins. No students attend
Council meetings, very few attend class meetings, very few
offer constructive ideas, encouragement or support to their
representatives. That being the
situation, it is ,easy for the most
to
enthusastic representative
rapidly loose his original enthusiasm and become discouraged.
Even the most promising new
class officers usually fall into a
state of inactivity, except for
carrying out certain obligatory,
inescapable functions. And so
the classes accomplish little or
nothing. The Student Council,
however, being a body of 17 men,
is usually able to provide itself
from within with the encouragement and cooperation that it
does not receive from without.
This year, due in large part to
the attendance record, I think,
the mutual encouragement and
cooperation that have to exist
among members of the Council
have been much less in evidence
than in the past. One can blame
those who have been absent most
for any deficiencies or shortcomings of the Council, or one
can blame the President of the
Council or all the members of
the Council. But ultimately, I
think, a large portion of the
blame must go to the student
body.

McCoy Poloi
To the editors:
In the Johns Hopkins catalogue for undergraduates a university is described as a place
of academic freedom where a
student has the opportunity of
working, searching and discovering knowledge. Unfortunately
I found that this was not the
case when I attempted to register for a course given only in
McCoy College. I was told that
according to the advisory committee of McCoy there are only
two excuses acceptable for a day
student to take such a course:
Either an unavoidable conflict
must be present of day school
courses or the course must lie
in the fields of education and
accounting.
Since this statement is so contradictory to academic freedom,
I would suggest that the university change its wording of the
subject in the undergraduate
catalogue. Most important, I believe would be an attempt by the
university officials to include
popular McCoy courses in the
day school.
Alan Nogen

THE ENGINEERS HAVE HAIRY EARS
Today in this age of technology when engineering graduates
are wooed and courted by all of America's great industries, how
do you account for the fact that Rimbaud Sigafoos, who finished at the very top of his class at M.I.T., turned down hundreds of attractive job offers to accept employment as a machinery wiper at the Acme Ice Company at a salary of $20 a week
with a twelve-hour day, a seven-day week, and only fifteen
minutes for lunch?
I know what you are thinking: "Cherchez la femme!" You are
thinking that Mr. Acme, head of the Acme Ice Company, has
a beautiful daughter with whom Rimbaud is madly in love and
he took the job only to be near her.
Friends, you are wrong. It is true that Mr. Acme does have
a daughter, a large, torpid lass named Clavdia who spends all
her waking hours scooping marzipan out of a bucket and staring
at a television set which has not worked in some years. Rimbaud
has not the slightest interest in Clavdia; nor, indeed, does any
other man, excepting possibly John Ringling North.
So how come Rimbaud keeps working for the Acme Ice
Company? Can it be that they provide him with free Marlboro
Cigarettes, and all day long he is able to settle back, make
himself comfortable and enjoy the filter cigarette with the unfiltered taste?

(Continued from Page 4)
Is it necessary for you to
display your sense of humor in
such a crude manner, to derive
pleasure from such obnoxious
print? Mores, is it necessary
for you to abuse the freedom of
the press with such worthless
words? Well, I guess it is—if
you haven't outgrown that thirteen-year-old stage of life.
Freud could attach some lovely phrases to describe your complex, retarded behavior, but I
find that "immature" does the
job quite well.
Marjorie Berson

Sorry Socialist
To the editors:
Having only recently received
copies of the News-Letter reporting our efforts to make the
Young Socialist available at
Hopkins University, I have finally been able to discover the
source of the conflicting testimony between Charles Vayne,
manager of the book store, and
myself. A phone call to Dean
Shaffer was enough to clarify
the unfortunate confusion. It
seems that Dean Shaffer, having told me that we had his

permission to place the Young
Socialist in the book store "on
the same basis as any other
periodical", directed me to negotiate with a Mr. Taylor, who I
understand, carries the title
"Plant Manager." It was Mr.
Taylor who instructed me that
he would not permit sale of the
Young Socialist at the book store
as it represented "only one point
of view, while Time, Life and
US News, presents all points of
view." Not being familiar with
Hopkins names, titles, or responsibilities, I assumed that I had
spoken to the Bookstore Manager. Allow me to publicly
apologize for having put such
foolish words into the Bookstore
Manager's mouth for which he
has just cause for righteous
indignation. Had Mr. Taylor
chosen to speak up, he could
have clarified the misunderstanding of titles.
It appears, however, that Mr.
Vayne, the Bookstore Manager,
has his own reasons for not
selling the Young Socialist "for
the reason that his (my italics)
book store does not handle
newspapers." Now, we must enter into a discourse on the definition of a newspaper,as opposed to a magazine, — both be-

ing periodicals. My, how the
lackeys of capitalism can twist
and squirm to dig up fine technicalities in order to prevent
Americans from reading "unkosher" thoughts, ideas, and information. Certainly, I can argue
that the Young Socialist is a
monthly magazine and Mr.
Vayne can retort that it is
printed on inexpensive newspaper print but why strain false
points raised by evasive bureaucrats.
The naked truth stands out for
all who have the honesty to see,
and that is that these men (and
those whom they represent), for
some reason which we would
all do well to investigate, do
not want to afford Hopkins students the opportunity to read
the Young Socialist. In order
to repair this deplorable abridgement of the right to read all
viewpoints in an academic institution, Hopkins students will
have to buy individual subscriptions to the Young Socialist until they organize themselves in
their fine tradition of fighting
for academic freedom to collectively resist this petty form of
tyranny over the minds of men.

No,friends, no. Rimbaud is not allowed to smoke on the Job
and when he finishes his long, miserable day he has to buy his
own Marlboros, even as you and I, in order to settle back and

Well, friends, you might as well give up because you'll never
in a million years guess why Rimbaud works for the Acme Ice
Company. The reason is simply this; Rimbaud is a seal!
He started as a performing seal in vaudeville. One night on
the way to the Ed Sullivan show, he took the wrong subway.
All night the poor mammal rode the B.M.T., seeking a helping
hand. Finally a kindly brakeman named Ernest Thompson
Sigafoos rescued the hapless Rimbaud.
He took Rimbaud home and raised him as his own, and
Rimbaud, to show his appreciation, studied hard and got excellent marks and finished a distinguished academic career as
valedictorian of M.I.T.
Rimbaud never complained to his kindly foster father, but
through all those years of grammar school and high school and
college, he darn near died of the heat! A seal, you must remember, is by nature a denizen of the Arctic, so you can imagine how poor Rimbaud must have suffered in subtropical
New York and Boston, especially in those tight Ivy League
suits.
But today at the Acme Ice Company, Rimbaud has finally
found a temperature to his liking. He is very happy and sends
greetings to his many friends.

By BARDY LEVAVY
After travelling to Ursinus
tomorrow, the Freshman basketball team plays its last home
game on Monday, February 13
against Drexel J.V.
Ed Greenberg led the freshman basketball team to victories
over PMC and Western Maryland, by scores of 56-48 and
69-58, respectively, by capturing
control of the boards and scoring
well.
In the P.M.C. game, Greenberg
was the Baby Blue Jays' prime
mover as he captured high of
22 rebounds, as well as 10 points.
Greenberg's helper in this
game was big Joel Sandberg.
Sandberg, after an average first
half, connected for 13 points in
the second half to complement
Greenberg's defensive work and
insure the victory. Phil Berger
with 11 and Mike Ratner with
10 were the other big scorers for
the Jays, with Ratner's work
under the boards being an excellent complement to Greenberg's
job there.
In the Western Maryland
game on February 6 at Homewood, Greenberg garnered 15 rebounds and scored 14 points in
the first half as the Jays jumped
to a decisive 24-13 lead at the
end of 10 minutes.
Schwartz Stars
In the second half, the frosh
proved that they were not a oneman team. Homer Schwartz,
who finished with 10, turned in
his finest offensive and defensive
effort of the season, and Mike
Ratner and Joel Sandberg also
turned in excellent accounts of
themselves. Sandberg scored 10
points, when he connected for
five of six shots. Ratner, who
finished with 11, turned in an
excellent offensive and defensive
performance, capturing 14 rebounds and playing a very fine
all-around game.
Perhaps the most inspired performance of the half, however,

Weiss, coming off the bench
with 7 minutes left in the game,
quickly proceeded to garner 6
rebounds and 11 points. He also
had the distinction of not missing a shot all evening, connectting for 3 for 3 from the floor

halves of a 1 and 1 situation.

scored three points all evening,

usual fine role as leader of the
Jays' floor game.

percentage of the team, which

fine performance, the fledglings
showed the effects of the twoweek examination layoff.
